I came up with an approach that computed a character distribution histogram for every string: you take a 64-bit field, split it up into 16 sets of 4 bits, and then compute the number of characters that are X modulo 16 for X = 0...15. For example, in the string "hello", the ASCII values of characters are 104, 101, 108, 108, 111, which are 8, 5, 12, 12, 15 modulo 16. In a 64-bit field, "hello" would thus correspond to a 0001 in the 9th, 6th, and 16th sets of 4 bits, a 0010 in the 13th set, and a 0000 in every other set of 4 bits. In the end, every string I had boiled down to a single 64-bit histogram.After computing these histograms for every string in the dictionary, I could compare them to the histogram of the search string and use bit arithmetic to quickly determine a lower bound on the edit distance. For example, if one string has 5 letters that are 3 mod 16 and 0 letters that are 4 mod 16, and another string has 0 letters that are 3 mod 16 and 5 letters that are 4 mod 16, then their edit distance will be at least 5 (i.e. it takes 5 edit edit operations if you replace 'aaaaa' with 'bbbbb'). Because the lower bound was almost always much higher than the distance threshold I was interested in, I could avoid the full Levenshtein distance computation about 99.99% of the time. In the 20th century, the island was then used to hold a mental asylum, and it currently lies abandoned and undeveloped. Any takers?20. During this period, the body of the deceased is wrapped in cloth, and is thought to wander around the village until the departed person is finally officially laid to rest.26. In these photographs, people would take a recently deceased family member and stage them, either in a family portrait or alone, as if the deceased was just sleeping or resting. Sadly, these people still looked totally dead.27. Dead and DazzlingHonestly, Victorian people were really weird. Eerily, he was wearing someone else’s clothes. He was in pretty bad shape, and died in hospital just four days later. Suppose MS has 1 million customers to whom it sells Windows at $150 a pop.BusinessesNow, businesses are a completely different thing. They buy almost exclusively volume licenses because they get a better overall deal but, here is the thing, they also buy lots of other stuff from MS, such as support incidents. Also, as they expand they upgrade, so you end up with a Windows Domain Controller, for example, and several Windows clients. Often they buy warranty, too, and other services. The bigger companies go straight out to Enterprise contracts which are a sort of all-you-can-eat buffet. They also costs a lot of money (obviously) but give customers complete peace of mind. This is where MS makes an awful lot of money.Now that we have set the stage, let’s see how MS has operated over the years.Private individualsMS has never had a really good reason to prosecute individuals: the cost of a lawsuit could well end up into the hundreds of millions, draining any profit that may come out of the segment. Worse, still, it would make MS look very bad from a PR standpoint, going after the little guy. Last, businesses are made of people, so the more people know how to use their operating systems the better chance they would advocate for Windows in the office.BusinessesThis is, instead, very different. MS has always aggressively pursued piracy from businesses, partly because they could make an example of them, partly because their Enterprise contracts keep them well in the black. Here, one lawsuit is enough to scare hundreds of small/medium businesses into compliance.Enterprises never really pirate because, for the most part, they don’t have to. As I already said, they are a sort of all-you-can-eat buffet, so there really isn’t even a financial reason to pirate software.Things have, however, changed.You may think that Linux, MacOS X, etc. have triggered the changes, but it’s not so. What triggered the change isHow did MS react to this? Well, it changed strategy.Clearly the old model wasn’t working out anymore, with the Enterprise contracts being at risk as well. That was the one thing that MS absolutely didn’t want to lose. But how do you keep paying customers who are clearly unwilling to use PCs?Well, you either do it indirectly or directly or both. Over the years, MS has offered a number of ISV (Independent Software Vendor) programs to allow new and struggling companies to use Visual Studio to create applications. Keep in mind that, while you can use apps on your phone, you can’t create them on your phone. You need a decent screen and a decent computer to do that. By incentivizing ISVs to use Visual Studio, they can keep a hold on the PC market for companies. But most of their power comes from a reinforcement cycle of private and business use, so… how can them keep a hold on private users as well? Simple: by transforming Windows in a service, i.e. a paid yearly subscription that is costlier as you go up in your needs. We are seeing this slowly happening, even though we’re not quite there yet. The various updates being pushed are, in essence, the foundation on which this Windows-as-a-service will be built. This is also why MS has tried all kinds of dirty tricks to get users updated to Windows 10.If you’ve followed the news from MS, you’ll probably wonder “what about the ads?”. Yeah, that. To understand that we need to make a foray into customer segmentation, so bear with me.Customer segmentsTo understand this, leave software aside for a minute. Consider, instead, products’ coupons. If you collect a certain number of coupons, you get some quantity of the product for free. Now here’s the thing: cutting those coupons and sticking them on a card is labour intensive and boring. Whoever does that? Old people, mostly, or people with little means. They see that as a worthy endeavour because they can get more product for essentially the same price. Also, they get coupons from family and friends who, ultimately, subsidise the purchase. Do you see where this is going? Those who are willing to spend more will subsidize those who are willing to spend less. But because the cost of the product per unit is far lower than even the cost the lowest payer pays, the company will still make more dough than it would have without coupons.This is, in fact, the perfect scenario for downloaded software: once built, the cost of download is minimal to none. You can make it available to billions of people without spending a dime more. Sure, coupons are much more difficult to manage, but that’s easily solved with service tiers: the bottom tier (which may end up being free) will have ads. The higher ones will not and will have increasingly more services. This is also the strategy used by Office by the way and it seems to be working quite well.How does all of this relate to piracy though?Quite simply, MS has understood that there’s no point trying to sue people or small companies for piracy: they can make them pay what the customer wants because then they can sell all sorts of services that are mostly profit. This means that, ultimately, nobody will be pirating Windows or Office because there will be no reason to do so.
